description: Since the 1870s; after Ancient Greek νεωτερίζω (neōterízō, “to (forcibly) innovate; to revolutionize”) (an -ίζειν (-ízein) derivation of νεώτερος (neṓteros), the comparative of νέος (néos, “new”))); neoteric +‎ -ize.

verbs.description: neoterize (third-person singular simple present neoterizes, present participle neoterizing, simple past and past participle neoterized)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) to neologize, to coin as a new word.
